newsitem.title: DENMARK: Copenhagen bourse keeps bond floor at four pct.
newsitem.headline: Copenhagen bourse keeps bond floor at four pct.

text.p: The Copenhagen Stock Exchange said on Tuesday that it would retain the current four percent rate floor for debt instruments until its next scheduled review, in December 1997, if market conditions allowed.
"If the market rate should change considerably during this period the Copenhagen Stock Exchange may announce a new minimum rate," a bourse statement said.
The floor rate is usually fixed twice-yearly -- in June and December -- according to an average of yields on specified fixed-interest, government and mortgage-backed bonds
It was cut to four percent from six percent in an extraordinary October 1996 adjustment after several expiring mortgage-backed bonds were replaced by smaller series, reducing the average.
The cut triggered a flood of four percent issues, attractive to local private investors for whom the low coupon provides tax advantages under Danish law.
